newsitem.title: RUSSIA: Yeltsin says Russia faces heavy burden of problems.
newsitem.headline: Yeltsin says Russia faces heavy burden of problems.

text.p: President Boris Yeltsin said in his annual state of the nation address on Thursday that Russia faced a "heavy burden of problems" and that ordinary people doubted the authorities' ability to tackle crime.
"Russia has entered the year of 1997 with a heavy burden of problems. The situation in the country is extremely difficult," he told parliament in a televised speech.
Yeltsin, 66, making his first major policy statement since he began his second term as president last July and had heart surgery last November, spoke clearly and firmly.
The prime concern, he said, was the economy.
"The rise of prices has slowed down but we did not manage to stop the fall in (industrial) output and increase the flood of investments," Yeltsin said.
Touching on Russia's problem of growing crime, he said: "Society is losing faith in the authorities' ability to fight crime."
